summary: Interactive Valentine’s/Rose Day website that culminates in an animated digital bouquet of roses assembled into a vase, written in first-person addressing the girlfriend as “you”.
imageRequirements:
## Required Images
- Romantic Rose Day background illustration with subtle paper texture and scattered rose petals (rose-day-bg.dim_1920x1080.png)
- Minimal elegant rose icon mark, flat vector style, transparent background (rose-mark.dim_512x512.png)

existing_features.title: Create a single-page interactive Rose Day (Feb 7) experience that addresses the recipient in first-person using “you” language (do not refer to the recipient as “she”).
Implement an interactive flow that culminates in a ‘finale’ scene showing a digital bouquet of roses in a vase.
Build a 3D first-person perspective bouquet assembly scene using React Three Fiber (Three.js) where the user can add roses one-by-one and see them animate into the vase.

Ensure bouquet construction logic aligns roses neatly: newly added roses should be positioned/rotated to form a visually coherent bouquet arrangement inside the vase (no random scattering outside the vase).

Add a simple narrative/interactivity layer before and during bouquet building (e.g., short Rose Day prompts, a ‘start’ moment, and progression text) to make the website feel interactive rather than a single static 3D view.

Add a coherent visual theme for the entire site (colors, typography, spacing, UI styling) appropriate for Rose Day/Valentine Week, and apply it consistently across screens and UI components (avoid default template look).
Create required custom static images and use them in the UI (served from frontend/public/assets/generated, not through the backend).

new_feature_requests.summary: Create an interactive Valentine’s/Rose Day website experience for the user’s girlfriend.
End experience with a digital bouquet of roses as the conclusion/finale.
Animate bouquet assembly: when flowers are added they align properly and are placed into a vase (first-person perspective).
Use first-person perspective language and address the girlfriend as “you” (avoid referring to her as “she”).

projectName: Interactive Rose Day (Valentine Week) first-person bouquet builder finale
